document.masterDocTitle: Three Species of Dactylogyrus (Monogenea: Dactylogyridae) Parasitic on Japanese Seabass Lateolabrax japonicus (Perciformes: Lateolabracidae) in Japan, with New Country Records for Dactylogyrus gotoi and Dactylogyrus kikuchii

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Three Species of Dactylogyrus (Monogenea: Dactylogyridae) Parasitic on Japanese Seabass Lateolabrax japonicus (Perciformes: Lateolabracidae) in Japan, with New Country Records for Dactylogyrus gotoi and Dactylogyrus kikuchii

paragraph.heading:
Dactylogyrus inversus Goto and Kikuchi, 1917
( Fig. 2 )

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Dactylogyrus inversum
[ sic ]:
Ji et al . 1982: 13
.

Microncotrematoides inversus :
Zhang et al . 1992: 131
;
Xia et al . 1999: 60
;
Wu 2000b: 424–425
, fig. 377.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined.
Seven of the 15 specimens deposit- ed (NSMT-Pl 6120) and three specimens deposited (togeth- er with two specimens of
D. gotoi
) (NSMT-Pl 6122), Lake Nakaumi , Shimane Prefecture , Japan ,
26 July 2012
; eight of the 22 specimens deposited (NSMT-Pl 6121), Lake Shinji , Shimane Prefecture , Japan ,
9 January 2013
.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 2.
Dactylogyrus inversus Goto and Kikuchi, 1917
, NSMT-Pl 6121. A, whole mount (ventral view); B, dorsal anchors; C, dorsal bar; D, hook of pair I; E, hook of pair III; F, hook of pair VII; G, needle; H, male copulatory organ; I, male genital organs (ventral view). Scale bars: A, 500 µ m; B–G, 10 µ m; H, I, 20 µ m. Abbreviations: an, anchor; ap, accessory piece; co, copulatory organ; es; eye-spots; hg, haptoral glands; hk, hook; ho, head organ; in, intestine; mg, Mehlis’ gland; od, oviduct; oe, oesophagus; ov, ovary; ph, pharynx; pr, prostatic reservoir; sv, seminal vesicle; te, testis; ut, uterus; va, vaginal duct; vd, vas deferens; vp, vaginal pore; vs, vitelline system.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Host. Japanese seabass
Lateolabrax japonicus
( Perciformes : Lateolabracidae ).
Prevalence and intensity range (mean). 80% (8/10) and 1–8 (2.2) in Lake Shinji; no data for Lake Nakaumi.

Remarks. The present species was originally described by Goto and Kikuchi (1917) from the gills of
L. japonicus
from Japan . It was also reported by Yamaguti (1938) from
L. japonicus
in the Seto Inland Sea, Japan . Yamaguti (1963) transferred the species to a newly erected genus
Microncotrematoides
. Yamaguti (1958) had also described
Microncotrema lateolabracis
from the gills of
L. japonicus
in the Seto Inland Sea, but Gussev (1967) relegated this monogenean to the synonymy of
D. inversus
and also did not recognize the genus
Microncotrematoides
as valid. Chen (1984) transferred
Microncotrema lateolabracis
to
Dactylogyrus
as
D. lateolabracis
, which, however, has been regarded as a synonym of
D. inversus (
Gibson et al . 1996
)
. The species has so far been reported from Japan ( Yamaguti 1938 , 1958 , 1963 ), China ( Gussev 1967 ;
Ji et al . 1982
; Chen 1984 ; Wu and Wang 1991 ;
Zhang et al . 1992
, 2001 , 2003 ;
Gibson et al . 1996
;
Xia et al . 1999
; Wu 2000b ; Ding and Liao 2004 ;
Šimková et al . 2006
) and the Russian Far East ( Gussev 1985 ;
Gerasev et al . 2008
). The specimens examined in this study conform to the descriptions and illustrations of
D. inversus
provided by Goto and Kikuchi (1917) from Japan and by Wu (2000b) from China . This species has also been reported from the chub mackerel
Scomber japonicu
s Houttuyn, 1782 ( Perciformes : Scombridae ) in Japan ( Ishii and Sawada 1938a ). However, despite later examination of
S . japonicu
s for parasites in Japanese water (
Ichihara et al . 1968
), there has been no rediscovery of
D . inversus
on this host. It is possible that Ishii and Sawada (1938a) misidentified or otherwise confused the hosts.
